data.title: Copy-Paste and other keyboard functionality stops working
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.0 (b8cd5b9556d8b70ea560d35b903422363f6c5c40, 2017-07-10T18:36:31.751Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
spellright|ban|1.0.27
prettify-json|moh|0.0.3
cpptools|ms-|0.12.0
PowerShell|ms-|1.4.1
debugger-for-chrome|msj|3.1.6



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Use vscode for a while

Result: Copy-paste stops working. In addition, other keyboard functionality stops working. For example, if I try to find find some text (Ctrl-F) and then press the Escape key, it will no longer close the find fields. If I close and re-open vscode, the problem is solved (for a while).

I've had this sporadic issue with all versions of vscode, but the problem seems much worse with the most recent version. It happens soon after I re-start.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: EH debugging: use a better name for the launch config's preLaunchTask
data.body:
(from a gitter question)

Currently the generated launch.json for the "hello world" extension uses a "preLaunchTask" named "npm" which confuses users, because they think that this is the raw "npm" command.

But this "npm" refers to the "npm" task configured in the task.json.
Only after understanding this connection it becomes clear what this "npm" really means:

```json
    // we run the custom script "compile" as defined in package.json
    "args": ["run", "compile", "--loglevel", "silent"],
```

I suggest that we rename the "npm" task to something more expressive like "compileAndWatch".

data.title: Auto indent doesn't outdent in nested scss map
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.0 (b8cd5b9556d8b70ea560d35b903422363f6c5c40, 2017-07-10T18:24:22.120Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.6.0
---

I've found a bug with the new auto indent feature while using nested scss maps.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Get a nested map inside a file with scss syntax.
2. Move a line down with your keyboard and see the following effect:
![vscode-autoindent-scssmap](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3918317/28118335-e3f2209e-6710-11e7-9923-a73ae28b1c20.gif)

Above you'll see mixed tabs and spaces appear, but setting the file to only use spaces doesn't solve the problem.

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

Hope this helps!

edit: added the example code so you can to try yourself:
```
$scss-config-map: (
    columns: 12,
    fluid: true,
    font-sizes: (
        B:  100%,
        M:  1.5rem,
        L:  3rem
    ),
    gutter: 20px,
    layouts: (
        S:  370px,
        M:  610px,
        L:  850px,
        XL: 1090px
    ),
    max-width: 1330px,
    min-width: 320px
);
```

data.title: start debugging "Cannot connect to runtime process, timeout..."  error
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.14
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.5

When I start debugging, I get this error: 
```
Cannot connect to runtime process, timeout after 20000 ms - (reason: Cannot connect to the target: connect ECONNREFUSED 127.0.0.1:21937).
```
But VSCode Version 1.13 is OK. I have saw that the debug console info is different between the two versions. In the console log of Version 1.14, there is one more parameter **--inspect=21937**.
The following is the log info:
```
// V1.14
... node_modules/electron/dist/electron.app/Contents/MacOS/electron --inspect=21937 --debug-brk --nolazy app/main.js 

// V1.13
node_modules/electron/dist/electron.app/Contents/MacOS/electron --debug-brk=36090 --nolazy app/main.js 
```

And here is my launch.json:
```
{
    "version": "0.2.0",
    "configurations": [
        {
            "timeout": 20000,
            "name": "启动",
            "type": "node",
            "request": "launch",
            "program": "${workspaceRoot}/app/main.js",
            "stopOnEntry": false,
            "args": [],
            "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
            "preLaunchTask": null,
            "runtimeExecutable": "${workspaceRoot}/app/node_modules/electron/dist/electron.app/Contents/MacOS/electron",
            "runtimeArgs": [
                "--nolazy"
            ],
            "env": {
                "NODE_ENV": "development",
                "DEBUG": "device, recium, script, socketServer, tracker"
            },
            "sourceMaps": true
        }
    ]
}
```
Is this a bug or something wrong with my launch.json file?

data.title: The find windows still hides the first line when it wraps.
data.body:
Following the fixes in #5525 (#10662, #24994, etc) the first line of content is moved below the search box when it's open.
However, it still seems to have issues with word wrapping in 1.13.1.
When the first line is short, it is moved down fully below the find window.
When it's too long and wraps, the line isn't moved down as far, and is still half occluded.

1. Ensure wordwrap is on
   "editor.wordWrap": "on"
2. Type this into a new text window (expanding to make sure it wraps):
   > abc abc abc abc abc abc abc abc abc abc abc abc abc abc abc abc abc abc abc abc abc abc abc abc abc abc abc abc abc abc abc abc abc abc abc abc abc abc abc abc abc abc abc abc abc abc abc abc abc abc abc
3. press ctrl+f

data.title: Make the scroll beyond last line show to two lines of code at the top, not one
data.body:
I had this at the other day:

Prerequisites: Uses an empty line feed at every file.

1. Looks at an empty file in awe, why it's empty...
2. Restarts Code, because that always helps to everything.
3. Still empty file.
4. Checks GitHub, yep the file is there.
5. Comes back to Code and _scrolls up_, the file was there, I just didn't see it because of the empty line at the end.
6. Does a facepalm and realises why Atom shows two lines when scrolling beyond last line: because of the line feed.

data.title: Configure excludes is not suitable for mono-repos
data.body:
Probably related with #26337 and #16115

- VSCode Version: 1.14 insiders
- OS Version: Mac OSx El capitan

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create any kind of mono_repo, with subfolders including node modules
2. Intellisense will ask you to configure excludes very often

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

Basically the problem is that you can not exclude recursive subdirectories. I have a mono-repo structure, where each package has it's own node_modules folder. I tried with all kind of exclude patterns, but none of them works

```json
{
    "exclude": [
        "node_modules",
        "**/node_modules",
        "**/*.log"
    ]
}
```

data.title: Unrequested (wrong) indentation
XSLT Emmet stopped working
data.body:
<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: Insiders 1.15.0-insider
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Make an XSL file with a basic XML structure
2. Type 'wh' + tab, it incorrectly expands to '\<wh\>\</wh\>'
3. Set "emmet.useNewEmmet":false in preferences
4. Type 'wh' + tab in the XSL file... it expands (correctly) to: '<xsl:when test=""></xsl:when>'

Same for other xsl emmet extensions.

'if' expands to '\<if\>', but should expand to '<xsl:if test=""></xsl:if>'

data.title: Make update process faster on Windows
data.body:
I'm in a corp environment where we have a policy-driven on-demand virus scanner. This painfully slows down the update process of VS Code due to the scanning of every individual .js file.

I'm using a HP Z620 with SSDs... I can't imagine how slow it is for the average user with the same virus scanner.

Is there a way to 'bundle' the installation files together to increase speed during installation, or even maybe  update VS Code in the background and ask me for confirmation before the update-enabling relaunch?

data.title: Debug Active Bar - usability feature-request
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

I like to use Debug Action Bar but it's somewhat inconvenient - it covers open tabs and I must move it around constantly (see image):
![vsc-old](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30110941/28110505-555e579a-66fb-11e7-99ac-e0e41e0695fb.jpg)

Suggestion:
Please, add a config file option "debug.actionBarPosition": "default" || "workbench".
"default" or not specified - classic behavior
"workbench" - debug controls are moved to workbench (see image):
![vsc-debug](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30110941/28111212-6bcac1b0-66fd-11e7-8c1d-8b9c9463501e.jpg)

For colored controls you can add third option if you like "workbenchColor" (see image):
![vsc-debug-color](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30110941/28111385-f5e01d0a-66fd-11e7-8d65-6f51c98c08d9.jpg)

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.14
- OS Version: Windows 7

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Remove ["debug.hideActionBar": true] from VSC configuration (if any) or set it to "false".
2. Press [F5] to launch debugging session.
3. Debug Action Bar opens and covers open tabs.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Keep coloured toolbar in OSX fullscreen
data.body:
We have two projects, client and server. I configured workspace settings to have client be green, server be blue. Really useful.

Until however, I fullscreen one of them. Then the coloured toolbar disappears, which defeats the purpose of styling it in the first place.

Would love an option to keep showing it in fullscreen, just to keep that distinction in there.

This is useful:
![screen shot 2017-07-12 at 11 18 53 am](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9585787/28101631-07bed3ae-66f4-11e7-8b07-e1cdaf3ab37e.png)

This isn't so useful (in fullscreen mode):
![screen shot 2017-07-12 at 11 19 00 am](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9585787/28101635-09e603a0-66f4-11e7-965f-1f56877afe19.png)

data.title: NPM scripts not running with new task runner 2.0

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.14.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 CU
- Reproduces without extensions: Yes

I saw #28595 but this seems to be a slightly different problem. Just upgraded to v1.14 and trying the new task runner. But it's not working for npm tasks: it just outputs the npm help text.

tasks.json:
``` json5
{
    // See https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=733558
    // for the documentation about the tasks.json format
    "version": "2.0.0",
    "tasks": [
        {
            "type": "npm",
            "script": "compile",
            "problemMatcher": []
        }
    ]
}
```

Output:
```
> Executing task: npm run compile <


Usage: npm <command>

where <command> is one of:
    access, adduser, bin, bugs, c, cache, completion, config,
    ddp, dedupe, deprecate, dist-tag, docs, doctor, edit,
    explore, get, help, help-search, i, init, install,
[snip]
```

Using npm v5.0.3

In settings.json: `"terminal.integrated.shell.windows": "bash.exe"` (Git bash)

Additionally, the task runner only finds 1 of the 7 scripts in my package.json file.

Will provide more info if needed.

data.title: Debugging not working in version 1.14.0 using NodeJs 6 on integratedTerminal
data.body:
<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.14.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Launch debugger for NodeJs using NodeJs 6 and `console` set to `integratedTerminal`

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

Launch config:
```
{
	"name": "MyServer",
	"type": "node",
	"request": "launch",
	"program": "c:\\workspaces\\NodePlay\\MyServer.js",
	"cwd": "c:\\workspaces\\NodePlay",
	"console": "integratedTerminal"
}
```
results in 
```
PS C:\workspaces\loader> cd 'c:\workspaces\NodePlay'; 'C:\Program Files\nodejs\node.exe' --debug-brk=34103 --nolazy MyServer.js
At line:1 char:67
+ ... dePlay'; 'C:\Program Files\nodejs\node.exe' --debug-brk=34103 --nolaz ...
+                                                   ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Unexpected token 'debug-brk=34103' in expression or statement.
At line:1 char:30
+ ...  'c:\workspaces\NodePlay'; 'C:\Program Files\nodejs\node.exe' --debug ...
+                                ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
The '--' operator works only on variables or on properties.
    + CategoryInfo          : ParserError: (:) [], ParentContainsErrorRecordException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : UnexpectedToken
```

If I remove the `"console": "integratedTerminal"` line it works.

Using `"protocol": "legacy"` has no influence.

Using NodeJs 8 instead of NodeJs 6 avoids the problem - maybe because node is then executed from path instead as quoted string: `PS C:\workspaces\loader> cd 'c:\workspaces\NodePlay'; node --inspect=22224 --debug-brk MyServer.js`.

data.title: [Installer] Update failed when another user using VS code

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.14
- OS Version: Windows Server 2012 R2

Steps to Reproduce:
Background: We have a remote server and allow two developer log in for development by their account.
1. Two people open VS code for coding
2. Update available. One user click update then update VS code.
3. Another user VS code still running, update failed, and can't fallback. Must uninstall then re-install VS code. -  FAIL

I think it's better to end all VS code process when install VS code.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26138585/28109760-c94ab8de-6722-11e7-8648-5a9bcc1592b9.png)

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No


[**7/14/2017 Update**]
I found another issue about right click menu "Open with Code".
For two user login system, if one user install VS code and select add "Open with Code" option, his/her right menu display normally. But can't add the menu to another user's right menu. Another user need to re-install VS code. (Or provide a method how to add it to right menu?)

data.title: Path to OneDrive does not exist
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.0 (b8cd5b9556d8b70ea560d35b903422363f6c5c40, 2017-07-10T18:36:31.751Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.16232
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
html-snippets|abu|0.1.0
code-gnu-global|aus|0.2.2
ftp-sync|luk|0.3.3
cpptools|ms-|0.12.0
csharp|ms-|1.11.0
vscode-icons|rob|7.10.1
twig|wha|1.0.2



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install Windows Insider Build 16232
2. Turn on "Files on demand" in OneDrive
3. Try open folder on OneDrive in Visual Studio Code - "Path does not exist"
4. Set OneDrive folder to "Always keep on this device", wait for download and then try to open in Visual Studio Code - "Path does not exist"

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes
